content: Yes, Kafka's works have a timeless quality that allows them to continue to resonate with readers from all backgrounds and cultures. Despite writing in a specific historical and cultural context, Kafka's themes of alienation, social isolation, and the individual's struggle against the system are universal and relatable to people all over the world. His works are a reflection of the human experience that transcends time and place, which is why they continue to be studied and appreciated by readers today.
